## Example: Mineral composition versus growth

::::::: {.cols data-latex=""}
:::: {.col data-latex="{0.75\textwidth}"}

- **Goal**: study association between height $Y$ of tree (in cm) and mineral composition of needles:
  - Nitrogen $X_N$
  - Phosphorus $X_P$
  - Potassium $X_K$
  - Residual ash $X_r$
- Independent variables expressed in percentage observed in dried needles.

## Simple linear regression not possible

\begin{itemize}
\item Separate linear regression models
\[E(Y|X_P)=\alpha+\beta_P X_P\]
only allow to predict based on 1 mineral
\item More accurate predictions based on all minerals simultaneously
\item Separate models might \alert{not} show \alert{pure effect}
\begin{itemize}
\item $\beta_P$ is mean difference in length between trees that differ 1 unit in proportion phosphorus
\item \alert{Confounding}: even if phosphorus would not have influence on length, trees with higher level of phosphorus might be taller because they contain, for example, more potassium
\item Necessity to compare trees with different level of phosphorus, but same level of potassium
\end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

## Multiple linear regression

\begin{itemize}
\item Assume that 
\[E(Y|X_N,X_P,X_K,X_r)=\alpha + \beta_N X_N+ \beta_P X_P + \beta_K X_K +\beta_r X_r
\]
for unknown \alert{intercept} $\alpha$ and \alert{slopes} $\beta_N, \beta_P, \beta_K, \beta_r$

\item Now prediction based on multiple minerals possible

\item Confounding \alert{partially circumvented}: 
\begin{eqnarray*}
&&E(Y|X_N,X_P=x_P+\delta,X_K,X_r)-E(Y|X_N,X_P=x_P,X_K,X_r)\\
&&=\alpha + \beta_N X_N + \beta_P (x_P+\delta)+ \beta_K X_K +\beta_r X_r\\
&&\hspace*{1cm}-\alpha - \beta_N X_N- \beta_P x_P- \beta_K X_K -\beta_r X_r = \beta_P\delta
\end{eqnarray*}
$\beta_P=$ difference in mean length between trees that differ 1 unit in proportion phosphorus, \alert{but have same value for other explaining variables}
\end{itemize}

## Analysis of larches

Parameters estimated using least squares method

```

summary(model_l2)$coefficients
```

\normalsize
We say in this case that the association between phosphorus and length is \alert{adjusted} for nitrogen, potassium, and residual ash

## Tests and confidence intervals 

\begin{itemize}
\item Tests and confidence intervals for parameter $\beta$ based on
\[\frac{\hat{\beta}-\beta}{SE(\hat{\beta})}\sim t_{n-p}\]
with $p$ number of unknown parameters in model
\item Or directly using
\end{itemize}
```{r eval = FALSE} 
confint(model_l2)
```

## Analysis of larches 
\small
```{r echo = FALSE}
summary(model_l2)$coefficients
```

\normalsize
\begin{itemize}
\item \alert{95\% CI} for $\beta_N$ needs $t_{21,0.975}=2.08$
\[[97.76 \pm 2.08\times 24.57]=[46.66, 148.86]\]
\item \alert{95\% CI} for $\beta_P$
\[[256.97 \pm 2.08\times 169.91]=[-96.36, 610.31]\]
\end{itemize}

## Interaction or effect modification

\begin{itemize}
\item \alert{Interaction} or \alert{effect modification}: effect of variable $X$ on outcome $Y$ depends on third variable $Z$
\begin{exampleblock}{Examples}
\begin{itemize}
\item Effect of nitrogen on growth depends on proportion phosphorus
\item Pharmacogenetics: effect of steroids for asthma on lung function depends on certain genes
\item Gene-environment interactions: effect of certain genes on COPD depends on history of smoking
\end{itemize}
\end{exampleblock}

\item Model interactions through \alert{cross-product term}:
\[
E(Y|X_N,X_P)=\alpha + \beta_N X_N+ \beta_P X_P+ \beta_{NP} X_NX_P
\]
\end{itemize}

## Interpretation

\begin{eqnarray*}
&&E(Y|X_N=x_N+1,X_P)-E(Y|X_N=x_N,X_P)\\
&&=\alpha + \beta_N (x_N+1)+ \beta_P X_P+ \beta_{NP} (x_N+1)X_P\\
&&\hspace*{1cm}-\alpha - \beta_N x_N- \beta_P X_P- \beta_{NP} x_N X_P\\
&&=\beta_N+\beta_{NP}X_P
\end{eqnarray*}
\begin{itemize}
\item $\beta_{NP}$ is difference in nitrogen \alert{effect} between trees that differ 1 percentage in phosphorus
\item Decide whether nitrogen effect depends on quantity phosphorus can be done by testing if $\beta_{NP}=0$
\item $\beta_N$ is effect of 1 percentage increase in nitrogen when percentage phosphorus is 0
\end{itemize}

## Predicted association (left) and effect (right)

```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.height=6}
#needles <- read.table("./datasets/needles.txt", header = T, sep = "\t", dec = ".")
model <- lm(length ~ nitrogen*phosphor, data = needles)
cs <- coef(model)

nitrogen_plot <- seq(1, 3, length.out = 50)
phosphor_plot <- c(0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30)

predict_length <- function(phosphor) {
  length <- cs[1] + cs[2]*nitrogen_plot + cs[3]*phosphor + cs[4]*nitrogen_plot*phosphor
  return(length)  
}

par(mfrow=c(1, 2))
plot(1, type='n', xlim=c(min(nitrogen_plot), max(nitrogen_plot)),
     ylim=c(100, 300), xlab='Nitrogen', ylab='Length',
     main="Nitrogen-length association")
for (ph in phosphor_plot) {
  outcome <- predict_length(ph)
  lines(nitrogen_plot, outcome, type = "l", lwd = 2)
}

# manually place labels
text(2.55, 150, 0.15, adj = 0)
text(2.55, 200, 0.20, adj = 0)
text(2.55, 250, 0.25, adj = 0)
text(2.10, 280, 0.30, adj = 0)

phosphor_plot <- seq(0.15, 0.40, by = 0.1)
nitrogen_effect <- cs[2] + cs[4]*phosphor_plot
plot(phosphor_plot, nitrogen_effect, type = "l", lwd = 2,
     xlab = "Phosphorus", ylab = "Nitrogen effect",
     main = "Influence of one unit of nitrogen")
```

## Constructing statistical models

Statistical models are built hierarchically by adding or removing one predictor at a time:
\begin{itemize}
\item \alert{forward} model construction: starts from empty model
\item \alert{backward} model construction: starts from full model, i.e., one that contains all available predictors
\item \alert{stepwise} model construction: combination of both
\end{itemize}

## Constructing statistical models

\begin{itemize}
\item \alert{Forward} model construction: include predictors \alert{1 by 1}
\item After each inclusion
\begin{itemize}
\item verify if certain predictors in the model are no longer significantly associated with outcome
\item remove those \alert{1 by 1} until model contains only significant predictors
\end{itemize}
\item Repeat until no inclusion is significant \vfill
\item \alert{Backward} model construction excludes \alert{1 by 1} the \alert{nonsignificant} predictors
\item Until model only contains significant predictors \vfill
\item The included (excluded) predictor is ideally the one that is most (least) strongly associated with outcome, after verification for the other predictors in the model
\end{itemize}

## Constructing statistical models

\begin{itemize}
\item Example larches in \texttt{R}
\item Once all \alert{first order terms} have been verified, investigate \alert{higher order terms} (interactions, quadratic effects, ...)
\item This is \alert{not} done in \alert{exhaustive} way:
\begin{itemize}
\item because number of higher order terms can get very large
\item because \alert{problem of multiple testing} might sometimes lead relatively easy by mere coincidence to incorrect conclusion that certain higher order term is significant
\end{itemize}
\item Instead higher order terms will be considered for inclusion based on:
\begin{itemize}
\item biological judgment
\item insight from residual plots
\end{itemize}
\item Once final model is obtained, verify its virtue through residual plots
\end{itemize}

## Constructing statistical models

\begin{itemize}
\item How to build statistical models \alert{depends ideally from goal} of these models:
\begin{itemize}
\item make predictions
\item determine effect of an exposure on an outcome
\end{itemize}
\item To make predictions, previous strategy is sensible since it aims at avoiding \alert{overfitting}
\item To determine \alert{effect of an exposure} on an outcome, must make sure above all to adjust for all \alert{confounders}
\begin{block}{Confounder are factors}
\begin{itemize}
\item that are not comparable between exposure groups
\item in particular, that are associated with outcome and exposure, but are \alert{not influenced by either}
\end{itemize}
\end{block}
\end{itemize}
